Edgell, C.B., O.B.E., Hydrographer of the Navy The Admiralty, London, S.W.l. 14th October, 1938 Dear Sir, On October 24th we are expecting the arrival of I®-. J.C. Stirton, Chief Engineer of the California Arabian Standard Oil Company in San Francisoo. Mr. Stirton ex pects to spend a few days in London and then to proceed to Arabia where, among other things, he intends to familiarise himself with the Company's marine and terminal problems. It is very likely that Mr. Stirton will wish to have an opportunity to meet you while he is here and to have the benefit of any suggestions that you may care to give regarding these problems. He expects to be here about a week and Mr. Smith, of the Company's Marine Department, will be in London at the same time. I am sure we could arrange to call upon you at any time that might suit your convenience while they are here. The Company is considering the possibility of in stalling some storage tanks and other facilities at Djeddah and in this connection I have recently had a letter from Mir. Smith, who is now in Arabia, in which he says that in look ing over the charts for that vicinity he notes a considerablearea to the TTorth of the town that seems to be either sur veyed incompletely or to be rather free from coral shoals. Does the Admiralty have any unpublished data on the area concerned which Mr. Stirton and Mr. Smith might have an opportunity to examine. Mr. Smith has also asked me whether I can secure any information about the waters in the vicinity of the mouth of the Koeboe river in Sumatra. Can you possibly help me in any way in this respect? Yours faithfully, for CALIFORNIA STANDARD OIL COMPANY, LIMITED. R.L. If you could conveniently see Mr. Stirton and Mr. Smith while they are here, I am sure they would appreciate it very much. The questions I have raised regarding Djeddah and Sumatra could be dealt with at that time and I am merely mentioning them now so that if you can see Mr. Stirton and Mr. Smith you can be anticipating some of the questions they may wish to ask you. cc - Mr. H.R.Ballantyne, London RL/T.

titleInfo.title: Coll 6/89 'Saudi Arabia: Approaches to Jedda Harbour. Interest of Standard Oil Co.'

physicalDescription.extent: The papers are arranged in approximate chronological order from the rear to the front of the file.

Foliation: the foliation sequence (used for referencing) commences at the front cover with 1, and terminates at the inside back cover with 8; these numbers are written in pencil, are circled, and are located in the top right corner of the recto side of each folio.

mods.abstract: This file concerns the California Arabian Standard Oil Company's interest in erecting storage tanks at Jedda, which would involve making improvements to the harbour's navigational facilities in the process. The file features the following correspondents: the California Arabian Standard Oil Company, the India Office, the Foreign Office, and the Admiralty's Military Branch.Also included is a list of several other Political and Secret Department files, most of which appear to also relate to the construction or improvement of port facilities or infrastructure.The file includes a divider which gives a list of correspondence references contained in the file by year. This is placed at the back of the correspondence.
